Name: Temporal Consistency DSE

Documentation.Description:
Basic Concepts

The DSE functionalities are enabled by a Java application running within a server internal to the Madrid trial site in charge of performing periodically a temporal consistency analysis over the data stored in Cosmos GE. The results of the analysis are loaded into the database of the same internal server of the trial. A prototype web interface has been developed for testing the performance of the DSE. The screenshot in the figure below shows how the Temporal Consistency DSE is applied to the weather predictions coming from the weather forecasting module of the Madrid trial. Non-consistent predictions are detected and removed by the pre-processing algorithm.

Basic Design Principles

The DSE makes use of the Big Data Analysis - Cosmos GE and the HiveQL Client (Backend). HiveQL is a database querying language based on SQL that supports analysis of large datasets stored in Hadoop file systems, so it is used by the DSE for performing queries to the database programmatically.

DSE Interwork

GE Dependencies
Documentation.Preface:
Within this document you find a self-contained open specification of the aforementioned Domain Specific Enabler (DSE).

Please consult the appropriate pages on the FINESCE website in order to understand the complete context of the related FINESCE trials and this DSE.
Documentation.ReutilisedTech: The Temporal Consistency DSE relies on the Big Data Analysis - Cosmos GE and the Publish/Subscribe Context Broker - Orion Context Broker GE from FIWARE

Usage:
Installation guide

The Temporal Consistency DSE runs under Java JRE7, which can be downloaded from https://www.oracle.com/downloads/index.htm . The DSE comprises the following modules:
  • Java process for data analysis
  • Database for storing processed data, so that they can be shown through an user interface. For the reference implementation the database used has been SQL Server 2012.

The data analysis process consists of a .jar executable file. To run it, it is need to place the file within the Java installation folder, or modify the environment variable "classpath" directory where it is located.

Before running the process, it is needed to have access to Cosmos enabled by Telefónica, for which, the server where the analysis process runs must have a fixed public IP. Contact person from Telefonica for Cosmos, at the time of the implementation, was Francisco Romero Bueno ( frb@tid.es ).

To run the process, it is need to run the following statement through the command line:
java –jar {PATH_TO_FILE} /HiveClientProject.jar

The process will run continuously, conducting regular analysis of the data stored in Cosmos. These data are automatically saved to the database, so they can be displayed through any user interface.

In the Madrid trial a SqlServer 2012 database has been used, but with the appropriate connectors it is possible to use any other database engine.

The system uses a table in the database server where a record is kept for each execution of the data analysis algorithm. Each record contains the following fields:
  • fecha : datetime of the analysis
  • mensaje : body of the message
  • modulo : trial module which has generated the message (WF, MG, WSN or CCE).

The structure of the field mensaje , which contains the relevant information from the analysis, is shown below:
datetime$timestamp$parameter$average$difference$correct$last_prediction$correction_factor**
correction_factor** : tolerance * average_deviation

The script for table creation in the database is: 


CREATE TABLE [dbo].[FINESCE_hiveResults](
    [fecha] [datetime] NULL,
    [mensaje] [text] NULL,
    [modulo] [text] NULL
) ON [PRIMARY] TEXTIMAGE_ON [PRIMARY]

At this point the developer will have all the data to show through any appropriate GUI to the end user, or through an API.

Usage guide

The information model maps the following data:

a ) Load data: sample of measurement data retrieved programmatically from the weather forecasting module. Data load example:

Request 

http://orioncb_ip:port/updateContext
Content-Type:
    application/xml
Request body:
    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> 
    <updateContextRequest>
        <contextElementList>
            <contextElement>
                <entityId type="finesce_meteo" isPattern="false">
                    <id>finesce_meteo</id> 
                </entityId>
                <contextAttributeList>
                    <contextAttribute>
                        <name>temp</name> 
                        <type>C</type> 
                        <contextValue>4.89</contextValue> 
                    </contextAttribute>
                    <contextAttribute>
                        <name>humrel</name> 
                        <type>pct</type> 
                        <contextValue>0.88</contextValue> 
                    </contextAttribute>
                    <contextAttribute>
                        <name>precip</name> 
                        <type>mmh</type> 
                        <contextValue>0.0315</contextValue> 
                    </contextAttribute>
                    <contextAttribute>
                        <name>modviento</name> 
                        <type>ms</type> 
                        <contextValue>0.01</contextValue> 
                    </contextAttribute>
                    <contextAttribute>
                        <name>dirviento</name> 
                        <type>grad</type> 
                        <contextValue>265</contextValue> 
                    </contextAttribute>
                    <contextAttribute>
                        <name>cc</name> 
                        <type>pct</type> 
                        <contextValue>0.2</contextValue> 
                    </contextAttribute>
                </contextAttributeList>
            </contextElement>
        </contextElementList>
        <updateAction>APPEND</updateAction> 
    </updateContextRequest>

Response 

Response code:
    200 OK
Content-Type:
    application/xml
Response body:
    <updateContextResponse>
      <contextResponseList>
        <contextElementResponse>
          <contextElement>
            <entityId type="finesce_meteo" isPattern="false">
              <id>finesce_meteo</id>
            </entityId>
            <contextAttributeList>
              <contextAttribute>
                <name>temp</name>
                <type>C</type>
                <contextValue></contextValue>
              </contextAttribute>
              <contextAttribute>
                <name>humrel</name>
                <type>pct</type>
                <contextValue></contextValue>
              </contextAttribute>
              <contextAttribute>
                <name>precip</name>
                <type>mmh</type>
                <contextValue></contextValue>
              </contextAttribute>
              <contextAttribute>
                <name>modviento</name>
                <type>ms</type>
                <contextValue></contextValue>
              </contextAttribute>
              <contextAttribute>
                <name>dirviento</name>
                <type>grad</type>
                <contextValue></contextValue>
              </contextAttribute>
              <contextAttribute>
                <name>cc</name>
                <type>pct</type>
                <contextValue></contextValue>
              </contextAttribute>
            </contextAttributeList>
          </contextElement>
          <statusCode>
            200
            <reasonPhrase>OK</reasonPhrase>
          </statusCode>
        </contextElementResponse>
      </contextResponseList>
    </updateContextResponse>

Meteo class: The class of the information model which stores the load data is Meteo. This class supports all services to retrieve predictions.

Methods: There is a method for retrieving the forecasts of each weather parameter provided by the module. The method get temperature is provided below as an example.

Get Temperature: This method provides the temperature forecasts for a GPS location over a time interval. This method accepts GET parameters:

  • method It shall be a String, representing the format of output data. There are two possible values:
    • json
    • xml
  • fecha_ini It shall be an Integer representing a date in UNIX_TIMESTAMP format.
  • fecha_fin It shall be an Integer representing a date in UNIX_TIMESTAMP format.
  • last It shall be an Integer, representing how many values the service will provide.
  • number_of_hours It shall be an Integer, representing how many values the service will provide, starting on “fecha_ini”. This parameter can’t be used combined with “fecha_fin”.

Example

GET 

http://s414608724.mialojamiento.es/FINESCE/api/{module_name}/{function_name}/?parameters

Example using JSON 

http://s414608724.mialojamiento.es/FINESCE/api/wf/temp/?method=json&last=3&number_of_hours=3&fecha_ini=1421931600

REQUEST

ACCEPT     
    application/json

RESPONSE
Response code:     
    200 OK
Content-Type:        
    application/json
Response body:    
    {"meteo": [
        { 
            "parameter":"temp" ,  
            "value":"6.29" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 16:00:00" ,  
            "entity":"meteo" ,  
            "scope":"cell" 
        },
        { 
            "parameter":"temp" ,  
            "value":"6.98" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 15:00:00" ,  
            "entity":"meteo" ,  
            "scope":"cell" 
        },
        { 
            "parameter":"temp" ,  
            "value":"6.94" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 14:00:00" ,  
            "entity":"meteo" ,  
            "scope":"cell" 
        }
    ]}

                <scope>cell</scope>
                <timestamp>2015-01-21T22:10:18+01:00</timestamp>

            </ctxEl>

b ) Analyzed data: sample which provides the last analyzed values.

MeteoAnalysis class:_ The class of the information model which stores the analyzed data is MeteoAnalysis. This class stores the analysis results of the predictions stored in “Meteo” table and supports the service "predicciones ()" to retrieve the analyzed data.

This method accepts GET parameters:

  • method It shall be a String, representing the format of output data. There are two possible values:
    • json
    • xml
  • fecha_ini It shall be an Integer representing a date in UNIX_TIMESTAMP format.
  • fecha_fin It shall be an Integer representing a date in UNIX_TIMESTAMP format.

Example

GET 

http://s414608724.mialojamiento.es/FINESCE/api/{module_name}/{function_name}/?parameters

Example using JSON 

http://s414608724.mialojamiento.es/FINESCE/api/wf/predicciones/?method=json&fecha_ini=1421931600&fecha_fin=1421942400

REQUEST

ACCEPT     
    application/json

RESPONSE

Response code:     
    200 OK
Content-Type:        
    application/json
Response body:    
    {"meteo": [
        { 
            "parameter":"temp" ,  
            "value":"6.29" ,  
            "value_correction":"5.81" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 16:00:00" ,  
            "entity":"meteo" ,  
            "scope":"analysis" 
        },
        { 
            "parameter":"temp" ,  
            "value":"6.98" ,  
            "value_correction":"6.98" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 15:00:00" ,  
            "entity":"meteo" ,  
            "scope":"cell" 
        },
        {

            "value_correction":"6.94" ,  
            "timestamp":"2015-01-22 14:00:00" ,

        }
    ]}

Overview:
What you get

Temporal Consistency DSE is a module which can be used by client applications (e.g. Building Energy Management Systems) for applying processing algorithms to data streams (e.g. weather forecasts, sensor measurements) that are used as inputs by those clients, in order to detect erroneous/inconsistent data in those streams, and replace them with alternative values, calculated through an algorithm based on historical data from the same data stream.

The ultimate goal of this DSE is to help ensure that data inputs in energy management systems are accurate enough for its use in different applications. An example of such applications can be the calculation of: building models, energy control set points, or energy savings achieved through energy efficiency projects.
The reference implementation provided shows the application of the DSE for processing weather forecasts collected from an internet web service, in order to use the refined data as an input to a building remote energy control system.

DSE Version 1.0

Why to get it

A reference implementation of a module for processing data streams handled by Big Data Analysis – Cosmos GE and Orion Context Broker GE.

Target Usage

This DSE aims to be a module which can be integrated in energy management systems whose data inputs need to be processed in order to ensure their correctness and accuracy. It is therefore useful for energy management system developers and integrators, who can adapt the DSE in order to apply it to the specific data streams they need to process.

Open Specifications
